Venusaur.overview: Venusaur is a phenomenal sun sweeper in the current UU tier. Venusaur's defensive typing lets it set up on many common Pokemon like Tangrowth, Gastrodon, and Rotom-W, allowing it to clean teams with its Growth boots. With moves like Giga Drain for reliable recovery, a powerful 100-Base Power and sun-boosted Weather Ball, and Sludge Bomb or Earth Power, Venusaur is able to punch holes in many teams, as with a boost it 2HKOes nearly every Pokemon in the tier, barring Bulletproof Kommo-o and Chansey. With a Modest nature, it outspeeds every relevant Pokemon in the tier under sun except +2 Galarian Moltres. However, Venusaur is severely limited if sun is no longer active, being outsped and KOed by plenty of Pokemon like Salamence, Azelf, and Thundurus-T or used as setup bait for Pokemon like Galarian Moltres, Kommo-o, and Necrozma. Without a boost, Venusaur can sometimes be too weak to sweep, as common Pokemon like Rotom-H and Moltres are able to survive an unboosted hit and OHKO it back. Lastly, priority users such as Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine can pick off a weakened Venusaur.
Venusaur.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off can be used to remove Chansey's Eviolite while also nailing Nihilego and Chandelure, but generally Venusaur benefits much more from its other moves; it can OHKO Nihilego and Chandelure with Earth Power, and after enough boosts from Growth it can damage Chansey with Giga Drain and outheal the damage done by Seismic Toss.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: If Venusaur chooses to not run Earth Power, both Chandelure and Incineroar can stomach any of Venusaur's hits at +2 and take it out with a Fire-type attack. Rotom-H and Moltres are other Pokemon that can take an unboosted Sludge Bomb from Venusaur and KO it back with their Fire-type attacks.

Kommo-o: Kommo-o resists Giga Drain and is immune to Sludge Bomb and Weather Ball thanks to Bulletproof, so it can switch in and set up Stealth Rock, KO Venusaur outright, or use it as setup fodder if it's an offensive variant.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Special walls such as Chansey and Umbreon can take any of Venusaur's hits and stall out sun turns, with the former using Soft-Boiled and wearing it down with Seismic Toss and the latter being able to keep itself healthy with Wish + Protect and hit Venusaur hard with Foul Play due to Growth's attack boosts. Both Assault Vest Reuniclus and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can take a +2 hit and KO it back.

Priority Users: Zygarde-10%, Lycanroc-D, and Mamoswine can revenge kill Venusaur using their priority moves if Venusaur is worn down, which can happen due to Venusaur sometimes having to take a hit to set up Growth while also dealing with Life Orb recoil.

Opposing Weathers: Venusaur's sweeping capabilities can be halted by weather setters such as Alolan Ninetales and Pelipper cancelling Chlorophyll. This forces Venusaur out and Torkoal back in to reactivate sun, which can be taken advantage of by the opponent. Torkoal is also severely weakened by Stealth Rock if it has to come in multiple times during a game, and if it faints, Venusaur becomes dead weight.

sets.name: Chlorophyll Sweeper
sets.description:
Growth is a powerful setup move under sun, boosting Venusaur's Special Attack by 2 stages and allowing it to 2HKO nearly all the Pokemon in the tier. It can set up on popular Pokemon such as Tangrowth, Quagsire, and Tapu Bulu due to its typing, and then sweep through opposing teams. Giga Drain hits Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types like Primarina, Krookodile, and Rhyperior super effectively. Weather Ball is Venusaur's main attacking move under sun, as its Base Power becomes 100 and is boosted by the sun, KOing Steel-types that resist Giga Drain like Celesteela, Aegislash, and Jirachi. Sludge Bomb hits Pokemon that resist Giga Drain and Weather Ball like Salamence and Rotom-H while also hitting Fairy-types like Hatterene super effectively, though it will need a boost to OHKO the former two. Earth Power is an alternative option to hit Bulletproof Kommo-o, which resists or is immune to all of Venusaur's attacks, and has the added benefit of hitting Tentacruel, Chandelure, and Nihilego harder, but this leaves Venusaur susceptible to Salamence, as Giga Drain and Weather Ball are mandatory moves. Maximum investment in Special Attack and Speed ensures Venusaur is as strong and fast as possible. A Modest nature is typically used to maximize damage output while still nearly outspeeding everything under the sun, but a Timid nature can be used to outspeed +2 Galarian Moltres if needed. Life Orb is used to boost Venusaur's damage output, letting it OHKO Pokemon such as Rotom-H, Salamence, and Nidoqueen after a boost, while a boost to Giga Drain gives Venusaur insane damage output and reliable recovery, making it an unstoppable force.

Venusaur only fits on sun teams, so Torkoal is a mandatory partner, as it is the most reliable sun setter in the tier. It provides the team with entry hazard support and entry hazard control with Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, respectively. Other Pokemon that take advantage of sun like Chandelure and Charizard break holes in enemy teams thanks to their powerful wallbreaking capabilities amplified by sun, allowing Venusaur to sweep much more easily. Venusaur also appreciates momentum such as Teleport from Chansey to help it get in safely as well as give it more opportunities to set up; for example Chansey can bring Venusaur in on physical attackers like Krookodile and Azumarill, which are forced out by it under sun. Hatterene can be run as a Kommo-o check and discourages entry hazards from being set so Torkoal can come in more, allowing Venusaur to sweep more easily. Lastly, an offensive Kommo-o of your own can help the team deal with Pokemon like Chandelure while also giving it an easier matchup against Chansey.

Nidoqueen.overview: Nidoqueen is an exceptional wallbreaker and capable entry hazard setter because Life Orb and Sheer Force let it 2HKO the entire UU metagame bar Chansey and bulky Galarian Moltres. Its solid defensive typing also lets it check Pokemon such as Nihilego and discourage common Electric-types such as Rotom-H from using Volt Switch. However, Nidoqueen can struggle to pivot into Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus-T that commonly carry super-effective coverage to break through it. Unfortunately, Nidoqueen's overreliance on its Life Orb leaves it susceptible to Knock Off from Pokemon it would pivot into like Nihilego. A low Speed stat gives Nidoqueen an undesirable matchup versus faster-paced teams, and although Nidoqueen sports a quality defensive typing, it is still weak to common Pokemon in the tier such as Mamoswine and Keldeo. These struggles sting a bit more because Nidoqueen has no form of reliable recovery, meaning it is worn down pretty quickly throughout a match. Lastly, Nidoqueen faces severe competition from her counterpart Nidoking, who sports better offenses and a higher speed tier, making it preferred on most teams. Still, Nidoqueen's better bulk and role compression as an entry hazard setter gives it a role on certain teams.
Nidoqueen.comments:
Other Options

Nidoqueen can run a bulkier set holding Black Sludge, as it can somewhat take advantage of its bulk and defensive typing to better check Lycanroc-D lacking Psychic Fangs and Mienshao and do a better job setting up entry hazards, but this set struggles because it is somewhat weak. Taunt does a decent job of giving utility Pokemon like Chansey a hard time. Substitute can be a viable option to ease prediction on a forced switch. Protect also helps prediction by letting Nidoqueen scout Choice-locked Pokemon it is weak to such as Krookodile and Jirachi.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is the single best answer to Nidoqueen, as it can consistently switch into its attacks without worry, recover any damage away, and chip Nidoqueen with Seismic Toss.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types such as Azelf, Necrozma, and Starmie all can outspeed and KO Nidoqueen, with Necrozma being able to live a hit and use it as set up fodder thanks to its high natural bulk. Assault Vest Reuniclus counters Nidoqueen and can force it out with ease.

Water-types: The majority of Water-types in UU can outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen with ease. Keldeo can outspeed Nidoqueen and OHKO it with Hydro Pump, while Choice Band Crawdaunt OHKOes it with Aqua Jet. Milotic and Gastrodon can take hits and deal heavy damage back thanks to their high natural bulk. Tentacruel and Rotom-W can also force out Nidoqueen if Nidoqueen is worn down enough.

Faster Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D, Chandelure, Mamoswine, and Krookodile can outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen.

sets.name: Offensive Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description:
Nidoqueen is a reliable setter of entry hazards because of its above average bulk, ability to force switches, and good matchup versus hazard removers such as Salamence and Rotom-H. Stealth Rock is the better hazard choice for this set, as it provides excellent utility to just about any team, although Toxic Spikes is an option if the team has another Stealth Rock user. Earth Power and Sludge Wave are mandatory, powerful STAB moves that OHKO bulkier Pokemon such as Aegislash, Hatterene, and Tangrowth. Fire Blast is an excellent coverage move and the best pick for the last slot, as it almost OHKOes Amoonguss and cleanly 2HKOes Celesteela. Modest is the preferred nature because it grants Nidoqueen exceptional power and still lets it outspeed most of its primary targets, although a Timid nature can be used to outspeed Buzzwole, Timid Volcanion, and Timid Toxtricity. However, a Timid nature will make Nidoqueen noticeably weaker, missing out on benchmarks such as the guaranteed 2HKO on defensive Kommo-o.

Tapu Bulu pairs very well with Nidoqueen, as it appreciates Nidoqueen taking care of Amoonguss and Tangrowth and in return can check Water-types like Azumarill, Starmie, and Keldeo. Its Grassy Terrain also provides a bit of recovery to Nidoqueen. Wallbreakers such as Azumarill and Lycanroc-D make good teammates because they also appreciate Nidoqueen's good matchup versus Amoonguss and Tangrowth. In return, they can remove specially defensive walls like Chansey and Galarian Moltres. Starmie is a decent teammate for Nidoqueen because it checks many Pokemon that threaten Nidoqueen, such as Keldeo. Rotom-H and Rotom-W are both Volt Switch users that can bring Nidoqueen in safely and also check Mamoswine, and the latter has the added benefit of checking Krookodile. Nidoqueen pairs well with almost any Kommo-o set, as Nidoqueen can break through Primarina and Hatterene to help it succeed. Kommo-o sets using Stealth Rock also can let Nidoqueen run Toxic Spikes.

Ninetales-Alola.overview: Alolan Ninetales is the only relevant Pokemon in UU that can consistently set up Aurora Veil. Its great Speed tier allows it to set up Aurora Veil in front of common Pokemon like Keldeo and Zarude, and its access to support moves like Hypnosis allows it to gain momentum with a free switch and bring in frail sweepers like Diggersby and Thundurus-T more easily. Sadly, Ice / Fairy is not a great defensive typing, as Alolan Ninetales will drop easily to both offensive and defensive variants of Steel-types like Aegislash, Jirachi, and Celesteela, making it difficult to consistently get Aurora Veil up against some teams. Additionally, a lot of common leads can give Alolan Ninetales a hard time, such as Lycanroc-D, and Choice Scarf Jirachi KO it before it can set up Aurora Veil. Furthermore, the presence of rain in the metagame can hinder Alolan Ninetales's ability to set up Aurora Veil at times.
Ninetales-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Alolan Ninetales has access to Nasty Plot, which can significantly boost its offensive presence while maintaining some bulk investment. This lets it take advantage of its great offensive typing and Speed tier to try to sweep or do heavy damage on its own; however, it cannot break through most Steel- and Fire-types even with multiple Nasty Plot boosts. Encore can give a safe switch to gain momentum for any of Alolan Ninetales's teammates. It also can be used to shut down Pokemon that attempt to set up, such as Substitute Primarina and Swords Dance Aegislash.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Alolan Ninetales is in big trouble against any Steel-type Pokemon, in particular Choice Scarf Jirachi, which will OHKO it with Iron Head before it can set up Aurora Veil. Slower Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash take negligible damage from Freeze-Dry and will OHKO Alolan Ninetales even after it sets up Aurora Veil.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Moltres, Rotom-H, and Chandelure also resist Freeze-Dry, so Alolan Ninetales cannot do much against them. Rotom-H is a great Defogger against Alolan Ninetales, as it takes negligible damage from Freeze-Dry and can remove Aurora Veil immediately once it is set up, as well as threaten Alolan Ninetales with Overheat.

Faster Threats: Alolan Ninetales struggles against Pokemon that are faster and can threaten to KO it or hinder its ability to properly set up Aurora Veil. Lycanroc-D and Jolly Scolipede are faster and can OHKO it.

Weather Changers: Weather teams, in particular sun teams with Torkoal and rain teams with Pelipper, will give Alolan Ninetales a hard time trying to keep Aurora Veil up. Alolan Ninetales will typically need to carry Hail in order to counteract the effects of the changing weather.

sets.name: Aurora Veil
sets.description:
Setting up Aurora Veil at all costs is the main priority for Alolan Ninetales. Freeze-Dry is the only offensive move Alolan Ninetales needs, as it hits a substantial number of UU Pokemon such as Salamence, Gyarados, and Amoonguss for super effective damage. Moonblast allows Alolan Ninetales to OHKO Crawdaunt, Buzzwole, and Kommo-o. Hypnosis can be used to put Pokemon to sleep that threaten to remove Aurora Veil with Defog or after Aurora Veil is up to allow you to safely switch in one of your sweepers. It also can be used to cripple Steel-types like Aegislash that threaten to KO Alolan Ninetales, but at 60% accuracy, this is very risky. Hail is an option as well, although it is useful only against opposing weather teams like rain that try to cancel the Snow Warning hail. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Alolan Ninetales to ignore entry hazards and come in as much as possible to set Aurora Veil.

Alolan Ninetales fits exclusively on hyper offense teams, as only these teams can maximize the utility offered from Aurora Veil. Azumarill is typically a great partner, since it can help check Lycanroc-D with Aqua Jet. Azumarill can also use Belly Drum more easily under Aurora Veil and proceed to clean out most of the enemy team, as it no longer has to rely exclusively on Aqua Jet while Aurora Veil is up. Alolan Ninetales struggles against all Steel-type Pokemon, including slower ones like Celesteela, which can OHKO it through Aurora Veil. A partner like Krookodile or Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can help ease the pressure from these foes, the former also being able to support its teammates with Stealth Rock. Other good teammates include offensive Steel-types like Autotomize Celesteela and Swords Dance Aegislash, which can set up very easily under Aurora Veil to begin a sweep. Aegislash especially appreciates this as it can potentially activate a Weakness Policy more easily. Clangorous Soul Kommo-o and Dragon Dance Gyarados can also attempt to boost more than once under Aurora Veil. They both help pressure Fire-types like Moltres and Rotom-H, which would otherwise threaten Alolan Ninetales and remove Aurora Veil with Defog.

Tentacruel.overview: With incredible Special Defense, an excellent defensive typing that allows it to deal with threats like Primarina, Keldeo, and Celesteela, and the distinction of being one of the only viable Rapid Spin users in the tier, Tentacruel is a solid option for many balance and bulky offense teams. Its base 100 Speed and wide utility movepool that includes options like Knock Off and Haze allow it to outspeed threats like Nidoking and Chandelure and trade with top threats like Keldeo. While its Special Defense is excellent, its Defense and HP are fairly poor, making it difficult for Tentacruel to switch into strong physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Buzzwole. This is further worsened by Tentacruel's mediocre attacking stats making it difficult to acquire KOs and leaving it overly reliant on status, which worsen its matchup against foes like Buzzwole and setup sweepers like Galarian Moltres and Azelf. These weaknesses also put Tentacruel at a disadvantage against entry hazard setters like Krookodile, Nidoqueen, and Seismitoad, which can handle Scald, and make it difficult to remove entry hazards.
Tentacruel.comments:
Other Options

Toxic Spikes can be used to give Tentacruel its own method of setting up entry hazards, but it is unreliable due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and Amoonguss. Toxic lets Tentacruel cripple switch-ins such as Seismitoad and Salamence but is hard to fit. A more physically defensive EV spread of 252 HP / 236 Def / 20 Spe with a Bold nature is an option to check physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Buzzwole more effectively, but the decrease in Speed will result in Tentacruel getting outsped by threats like Mamoswine and Rotom-H. Clear Body can be used to better counter Sticky Web teams, but is not very useful otherwise.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric types such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Rotom-W severely dent Tentacruel with their STAB attacks. The latter two can also easily use Volt Switch on Tentacruel to generate free momentum.

Ground-types: Krookodile easily OHKOes Tentacruel with Earthquake, although it doesn't like having to take a Scald in the process. Seismitoad and Gastrodon are immune to Scald and resistant to Sludge Bomb, which means Tentacruel can only force progress by fishing for poison against them. Gastrodon also has reliable recovery, which makes fishing for poison even more ineffective.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o can easily switch into Tentacruel and force it out. Salamence and Noivern can also switch into it easily, although Tentacruel does have enough special bulk to stay in against them and remove their Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off.

Psychic-types: Hatterene, Reuniclus, and Necrozma easily OHKO Tentacruel with Psyshock or Photon Geyser, although Hatterene doesn't like taking a Sludge Bomb, and both Reuniclus and Necrozma don't like taking a Knock Off. Galarian Slowbro is especially troublesome for Tentacruel, as it cannot be poisoned and can easily set up on Tentacruel with Calm Mind.

Physical Attackers: Conkeldurr, Lycanroc-D, and Gyarados can muscle through Tentacruel due to its poor Defense. The former is especially dangerous, as unlike the latter two, it doesn't have to fear getting burned by Scald.

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description:
Sludge Bomb prevents Tentacruel from being too passive and hits foes such as Tangrowth, Tapu Bulu, and Azumarill. It also has a chance to poison, which is useful for crippling threats like Salamence and Suicune. Rapid Spin can provide a boost to Tentacruel's Speed, letting it outspeed common Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, Noivern, and Azelf. Knock Off cripples checks like Seismitoad and Gastrodon. Haze allows Tentacruel to shut down setup sweepers like Clangorous Soul Kommo-o, Calm Mind Primarina, and Belly Drum Azumarill, which can take advantage of its passivity. Black Sludge gives Tentacruel a form of recovery, which it completely lacks otherwise. Liquid Ooze punishes draining moves such as Leech Seed, allowing it to deal passive damage to foes that rely on these moves for recovery, like Celesteela and Amoonguss. A Timid nature and 144 Speed EVs allow Tentacruel to outspeed Mamoswine, Chandelure, and maximum Speed Rotom-W. The rest of the EVs are put into Defense to more easily deal with Lycanroc-D and Azumarill.

Tentacruel is best used on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to remove entry hazards. Entry hazard setters like Jirachi, Rhyperior, and Krookodile benefit greatly from Tentacruel removing Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off and clearing entry hazards solely from its side of the field, which let them fully capitalize on their entry hazards. Krookodile also sports crucial immunities to Electric and Psychic, which allow it to check foes like Thundurus and Galarian Slowbro for Tentacruel. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu provide switch-ins to some of Tentacruel's biggest checks such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Krookodile. The latter can also set up Grassy Terrain, which provides Tentacruel with another source of recovery and weakens Earthquake. Sylveon provides Wish support for Tentacruel, another form of recovery, and acts as a secondary check to Buzzwole and Keldeo. Pokemon like Salamence, Moltres, and Rotom-H appreciate Tentacruel's Rapid Spin allowing them to forego Defog. Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi are greatly valued as partners for Tentacruel, as they can check Psychic- and Dragon-types like Reuniclus and Kommo-o, which Tentacruel struggles with.

Slowbro-Galar.overview: Thanks to its amazing ability and typing, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro can act as a great late-game cleaner. Its resistances let it stomach hits from the likes of Nihilego and Amoonguss, and its Poison STAB allows it to threaten Pokemon such as Primarina and Tangrowth. Galarian Slowbro's decent bulk and Regenerator let it come in multiple times to spam Sludge Bomb or Scald, wearing checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon down through potential poison and burns. It can similarly cripple offensive checks like Krookodile, Zarude, and Keldeo, which it can take a hit from and then switch out. Regenerator lets Galarian Slowbro easily set up even if it's been weakened or forced out early-game, and it's very difficult to take out once it gets going with Calm Mind. Its immunity to Toxic also contributes to its longevity. Being capable of using Colbur or Shuca Berry forces Pokemon like Zarude and Mamoswine to scout for its specific Berry. However, its very low Speed for a sweeper lets Pokemon like Krookodile, Diggersby, and Azumarill revenge kill it. Its special bulk is not good before setting up, leaving it weak to special attackers such as Primarina and Galarian Moltres. Galarian Slowbro can easily become setup fodder for Pokemon like Calm Mind Reuniclus and Suicune. Furthermore, it faces competition with Reuniclus as a Calm Mind sweeper because of its Magic Guard and ability to beat Pokemon like Celesteela more easily. Reuniclus is also not weak to Ground, easing matchups against Pokemon like Gastrodon and Nidoqueen.
Slowbro-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots preventing entry hazard damage can create more setup opportunities. There exist Nasty Plot sets with Sludge Wave, Fire Blast, and either Psyshock or Grass Knot, with the former hitting Chansey and Chandelure and the latter hitting Krookodile harder. They use Quick Draw + Quick Claw to let Galarian Slowbro bypass its Speed sometimes, but this makes it lose a lot of bulk and become extremely vulnerable to Chandelure, Mamoswine, and Krookodile.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Band Krookodile, Crawdaunt, and Galarian Moltres scare Galarian Slowbro with their Dark-type attacks. The former two do huge amounts of damage to Shuca Berry Galarian Slowbro, and even after consuming its Colbur Berry, Knock Off still does a good chunk. Galarian Moltres takes advantage of Galarian Slowbro's bad Special Defense before it sets up. They all have to be wary of poison and burns from its attacks, though.

Ground-types: Unaware Quagsire doesn't care about Galarian Slowbro's boosts. Rhyperior, Mamoswine, and Krookodile can remove Galarian Slowbro with their powerful Earthquakes, but they have to be wary of Scald and potential burns. Furthermore, they should only be brought in to revenge kill Galarian Slowbro and while knowing its item, as Shuca Berry can negate its Ground weakness.

Powerful Special Attackers: Threats like Choice Specs Primarina, Nasty Plot Thundurus, and Chandelure take advantage of Galarian Slowbro's poor Special Defense before it can set up. However, they don't like switching in and risking getting statused or badly damaged.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Galarian Slowbro to muscle through checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon. Psyshock has great synergy with Flamethrower, the former hitting Nihilego and Chansey while the latter targets Steel-types like Aegislash. Sludge Bomb is an option to cripple Pokemon like Galarian Moltres and Crawdaunt, while also doing more damage to Primarina and Hatterene. Scald is aimed at Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Krookodile, and it can burn physically offensive threats like Kommo-o. However, it will have a harder time dealing with Aegislash. Slack Off helps Galarian Slowbro pose a constant threat and set up on Pokemon like Celesteela. Shuca Berry does the same against Ground-types like Nidoking and Mamoswine. Kasib Berry lets you take a Shadow Ball from Aegislash and retaliate back with a boosted Flamethrower. Colbur Berry lets it take an attack like Zarude's Darkest Lariat and KO back. Safety Goggles is an option that lets Galarian Slowbro beat Amoonguss and stay in against Spore. A Bold nature and the given EV spread help against physical attackers such as Azumarill and Scizor. An EV spread of 252 HP / 152 Def / 104 SpD with a Bold nature avoids the 2HKO from Choice Specs Primarina's Moonblast, lets +1 Galarian Slowbro always take Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball, and improves its odds at beating Aegislash.

Tapu Bulu is an exceptional teammate for its Grassy Terrain, which allows Galarian Slowbro to face Ground-types like Mamoswine and Rhyperior more easily. Tapu Bulu also takes on dangerous threats like Crawdaunt, while Galarian Slowbro removes Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth can remove Krookodile and Rhyperior, some the largest Ground-type threats to Galarian Slowbro. Due to Galarian Slowbro's low Speed, pivots that can get it in safely against setup fodder are ideal teammates. Jirachi and Zarude can use U-turn in front of Pokemon like Celesteela and Buzzwole. Raikou and Rotom-W can use Volt Switch on Grass-types and offensively check Chandelure. Galarian Slowbro appreciates Mienshao and Buzzwole checking Dark-types such as Krookodile and Crawdaunt. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Salamence and Rotom-W is needed. Strong wallbreakers like Choice Band Krookodile and Buzzwole can remove Calm Mind sweepers that beat Galarian Slowbro one-on-one like Suicune and Reuniclus.

Chansey.overview: Chansey's sky-high, Eviolite-boosted special bulk allows it to wall nearly every special attacker in UU, including fearsome threats such as Nidoking, Primarina, and Nihilego. In addition, Chansey can withstand certain physical attacks from setup sweepers like Gyarados and Salamence before they are sufficiently boosted and cripple them with Toxic. Chansey is also hard to wear down, since it has Soft-Boiled for HP recovery and Natural Cure to remove status ailments. It also has many utility moves such as Teleport, Stealth Rock, and Heal Bell to support its team. However, Chansey is rather passive, as it relies on Seismic Toss and Toxic to deal damage. As a result, many Pokemon such as Aegislash, Galarian Slowbro, and Reuniclus, easily take advantage of Chansey. Without Teleport, Chansey is a huge momentum drain for non-stall teams. Chansey's typing provides few useful resistances, and Chansey by itself must rely on its bulk to keep threats in check. Since it is unable to use Heavy-Duty Boots, Chansey is vulnerable to every entry hazard, meaning it gets overwhelmed by them quickly. Chansey is also susceptible to Knock Off and Trick, as without Eviolite, it is harder for Chansey to keep threats in check.
Chansey.comments:
Other Options

Chansey can run Counter to surprise physical attackers. However, it's hard to fit over another move, works only once as a lure, and depends on prediction. Wish is helpful to heal teammates, especially those without a reliable recovery move. However, Chansey prefers the one-turn recovery in Soft-Boiled to be a reliable wall. Additionally, many Pokemon on stall teams have reliable recovery and prefer the Stealth Rock or Heal Bell support. Confide is an niche option to prevent Calm Mind users such as Chandelure, Reuniclus, and Galarian Slowbro from setting up on Chansey.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fighting-types such as Kommo-o, Buzzwole, and Keldeo can easily break through Chansey with their powerful STAB moves. Strong physical attackers with Fighting-type coverage such as Aegislash, Lycanroc-D, and Tapu Bulu are also able to break through Chansey easily. However, all but Conkeldurr dislike being crippled by Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Diggersby, Mamoswine, and Azumarill can break through Chansey despite its Defense investment with their powerful moves or weaken it by removing its Eviolite with Knock Off. However, most fear Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Bulky setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Aegislash, Calm Mind Reuniclus, and Galarian Slowbro are immune to Toxic and take advantage of Chansey's passive nature.

Knock Off and Trick: Every Knock Off user, including Krookodile, Thundurus, and Tangrowth is a huge threat to Chansey, as once it loses its Eviolite, it is harder for it to switch into attacks. Trick users like Jirachi and Chandelure limit Chansey's effectiveness by crippling it with a Choice item.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Seismic Toss makes Chansey less passive, since it deals reliable damage to all but Ghost-types. Toxic helps Chansey wear down opposing Pokemon, especially bulky foes like Salamence, Tangrowth, and Moltres. Teleport is a great support move to bring other teammates safely onto the battlefield and to keep up momentum. Since Chansey has little to fear from many special attackers, it can force switches and get many opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Chansey can use Heal Bell to support its teammates. Thunder Wave can be used instead of Toxic to support slow teammates, but it makes Chansey weaker against bulky Pokemon and has less use overall. Maximum investment in Defense and HP alongside a Bold nature allows Chansey to check Psyshock Starmie and Hatterene as well as weaker physical attackers such Rhyperior more effectively.

Chansey can fit on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams as a sturdy wall for special attackers. Sturdy physical walls such as Tangrowth, Buzzwole, and Kommo-o check threatening wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-D and Diggersby for Chansey. In return, Chansey checks strong special attackers such as Nidoking, Moltres, and Primarina. Wallbreakers such as Thundurus, Lycanroc-D, and Crawdaunt appreciate Teleport Chansey's ability to bring them safely onto the battlefield. Since entry hazards limit Chansey's ability to switch into attacks and force it to recover more, entry hazard control from Salamance, Hatterene, and Rotom-W is crucial. Unaware Pokemon like Quagsire and Pyukumuku as well as Haze Mantine and Tentacruel can check threatening setup sweepers like Aegislash, Reuniclus, and Galarian Slowbro. Choice Scarf Ditto is also an option to keep offensive setup sweepers like Kommo-o, Azumarill, and Gyarados in check. A good Knock Off absorber such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, or Cobalion is helpful, as Chansey needs Eviolite to better switch into attacks. Amoonguss is also able to check Keldeo and Azumarill.

Starmie.overview: With a variety of coverage moves like Ice Beam and Psyshock alongside a great Speed tier to outrun top UU Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Salamence, Starmie is a solid offensive threat in the UU metagame, being able to threaten nearly the entire tier for super effective damage and 2HKO most of it. Starmie's wide coverage allows it to force many switches, and its ability Analytic severely punishes nearly all of them. Starmie also has great utility options: access to reliable recovery in Recover allows it to check Pokemon like Celesteela and Keldeo more reliably, while Rapid Spin lets it clear entry hazards thanks to its solid matchup against common setters like Rhyperior and Nihilego. However, while Starmie's attacks can hit exceptionally hard, specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Tangrowth are able to take non-Analytic-boosted attacks and take advantage of it. Other Pokemon like Aegislash and Rotom-W have enough bulk to take a hit from Starmie and threaten it in return. Furthermore, Starmie is prone to being worn down by entry hazards and Life Orb recoil, forcing it to use Recover more than it would like and limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker. Starmie also struggles to fit all the coverage options it wants into one set. Lastly, Starmie's vulnerable typing and frailty causes it to be easily revenge killed by common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude.
Starmie.comments:
Other Options

Thunderbolt can be used over Psyshock or Recover to break through Mantine, Celesteela, Pelipper, and Primarina more easily; however, with the exception of Mantine, the rest can easily be worn down by its other coverage options. Scald can be run to cripple physical attackers with a burn, but the power drop is noticeable. A Heavy-Duty Boots pivot set with Natural Cure, Rapid Spin and Flip Turn is possible due to Starmie's excellent Speed tier and strong matchup against common entry hazard setters like Nidoqueen and Krookodile. It acts as an effective hazard control and status absorber while also being able to pivot out of a bad matchup against a Grass-type like Amoonguss with Flip Turn. However, this set is too passive and doesn't provide as consistent utility as other Water-types like Primarina and Rotom-W.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, Mienshao, and Zarude outspeed Starmie and KO it due to its frailty, and Noivern naturally outspeeds Starmie and heavily damages it with its Draco Meteor. Additionally, Starmie must watch out for Aegislash, which can severely dent it with Shadow Sneak. Other priority move users like Zygarde-10% and Lycanroc-D can also pick off a weakened Starmie.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Common specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Gastrodon, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all take Starmie's attacks and limit it in their own ways. The former two can status it, hampering Starmie's longevity, while the latter can deal solid damage to Starmie with Giga Drain.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Hydro Pump deals devastating damage to common Pokemon like Jirachi, Rotom-H, and Nidoking. Alternatively, Surf can be used for increased accuracy but slightly less power. Ice Beam threatens Grass-types like Tangrowth and Zarude as well as Dragon-types like Salamence. Psyshock hits Pokemon like Chansey, Amoonguss, Keldeo, and Rotom-W harder. Recover is used to alleviate the Life Orb and heal off entry hazard damage, improving Starmie's longevity against foes like Keldeo. It can often use the move against common Pokemon it forces out such as Nidoking and Nihilego. Rapid Spin is an option to let Starmie clear entry hazards, but dropping Recover for Rapid Spin significantly diminishes Starmie's defensive capabilities as it struggles with longevity issues due to the lack of recovery. Life Orb combined with Analytic gives Starmie an incredible damage output, letting it 2HKO nearly the entire tier.

Starmie best fits on offensive teams due to its great Speed tier and solid wallbreaking power. Due to Starmie's frailty, it appreciates pivot support from Pokemon like Thundurus, Jirachi, and Rotom-H to get in safely against Pokemon like Rhyperior and Salamence. Rotom-H in particular likes Starmie's ability to deal with Ground-types like Rhyperior so it can freely use Volt Switch, and it also helps threaten Grass-types like Assault Vest Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Defoggers like the previously mentioned Rotom-H as well as Salamence help Starmie from getting worn down by clearing entry hazards, and both appreciate Starmie's ability to dispatch threats to them like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Kommo-o and Krookodile allows Starmie to break through opposing teams more easily, as it wears down Pokemon like Rotom-W and Chansey for it. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are notable partners for Starmie, as they are able to deal with faster threats like Choice Scarf Krookodile and Choice Scarf Zarude for it. Both appreciate Starmie pressuring troublesome Pokemon like Moltres and Salamence for them in return. Pokemon like Rhyperior and Nihilego can be paired with Starmie to help it answer threats like Salamence, as Starmie can get overwhelmed due to its proneness to being worn down and its lack of bulk.

Gyarados.overview: Gyarados is one of the most powerful setup sweepers in UU due to its fantastic coverage and combination of Dragon Dance and Moxie, which allow it to muscle through almost everything in the tier. Great coverage moves like Ice Fang help it break through bulky foes like Amoonguss and Salamence, and Power Whip allows it to hit Rotom-W and beat standard Unaware walls like Quagsire and Pyukumuku, unlike many other physical sweepers like Azumarill. It has good HP and respectable bulk, allowing it to withstand attacks while setting up. Unfortunately, its only Flying-type STAB move is Bounce, which has low accuracy and is exploitable because it requires two turns to use without Power Herb. Unboosted Gyarados is outsped by many common threats such as Thundurus and Nihilego. Even at +1 Speed, it will still get outsped by common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Mienshao. Gyarados struggles against defensive Pokemon like Celesteela and, if lacking Bounce, Buzzwole.
Gyarados.comments:
Other Options

A Substitute set with Waterfall, Bounce, and Leftovers as an item can help Gyarados break through defensive teams, as Substitute blocks status and Gyarados can easily boost multiple times against foes like Celesteela. However, the lack of coverage causes it to struggle with foes like Rotom-W and Quagsire.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Raikou, Thundurus, and Rotom-W reliably outspeed and KO Gyarados. While they can also withstand an unboosted hit, Rotom-W loses to boosted Power Whip, while Raikou and Thundurus cannot consistently tank multiple hits.

Physical Walls: Walls can be challenging for Gyarados, as it requires multiple boosts to KO them. Buzzwole can safely switch in on Gyarados and KO back with Stone Edge or cripple it with Toxic, though it has to be wary of Bounce. Celesteela can also withstand Waterfall after several boosts. Rocky Helmet Tangrowth can give Gyarados problems if it does not have Bounce, as +1 Ice Fang does not 2HKO. Chansey can also withstand several boosted hits and cripple Gyarados with Toxic and Thunder Wave.

Choice Scarf Users: Gyarados is slow, and many Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude will outspeed it at +1 and deal heavy damage with STAB or coverage moves. Gyarados needs to boost to +2 Speed to overcome these threats.

sets.name: Dragon Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Ice Fang hits Dragon- and Grass-types like Salamence, Kommo-o, and Tapu Bulu. However, Gyarados requires multiple boosts to reliably KO bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss with it. Bounce can be used over Ice Fang, as it can more reliably KO a chipped Amoonguss with just one boost and is Gyarados's best means of breaking through Buzzwole. While Bounce can be used without Power Herb, not running Power Herb makes Bounce easy to exploit with Protect, Substitute, or switching. Power Whip offers essential coverage against bulky Water-types like Seismitoad and Rotom-W. It also allows Gyarados to break through the Unaware Pokemon Quagsire and Pyukumuku. Moxie is the preferred ability, as it enables Gyarados to snowball through a team after one or two boosts. Intimidate can be used on a more balance-oriented team to set up more freely against physical foes, but it notably lessens Gyarados's sweeping potential. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Stealth Rock damage, allowing Gyarados to switch in more frequently. Lum Berry can also be used to freely set up twice against foes like Amoonguss and Chansey. An Adamant nature can be used for additional wallbreaking power, as it guarantees OHKOing Azumarill with unboosted Power Whip as well as Thundurus with +1 Ice Fang. Jolly can be used to outspeed Pokemon like Chandelure and Togekiss unboosted.

Gyarados is best used on hyper offense and bulky offense teams due to the offensive pressure it offers. Gyarados is primarily used as a late-game cleaner, but it struggles against defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Amoonguss. A teammate that offers entry hazard support like Krookodile and Kommo-o helps wear these foes down enough for Gyarados to break through them. Krookodile also absorbs Electric-type attacks and, with a Chople Berry, can lure in and remove Lycanroc-D, a foe Gyarados is in danger of being revenge killed by. Klefki can provide Spikes support to help wear down foes like Buzzwole and Amoonguss. Diggersby forces a lot of damage onto Celesteela, Buzzwole, and Chansey, allowing Gyarados to clean these typically bulky threats up more easily. Sticky Web setters like Shuckle and Slurpuff can make up for Gyarados's mediocre Speed tier and prevent Choice Scarf users like Krookodile revenge killing it.

Ditto.overview: The combination of Imposter and Choice Scarf allows Ditto to outspeed the foe, making it a strong setup deterrent and one of the best revenge killers to sweepers like Thundurus, Salamence, and Kommo-o. Ditto also has utility against stall teams, as it cannot be easily PP stalled, especially if it is able to switch into Knock Off from defensive Tangrowth, and can take advantage of transforming into opposing clerics like Umbreon and Chansey. However, Ditto can be awkward to fit onto teams, as it often cannot switch into anything safely or provide any defensive utility outside of Regenerator. Imposter also fails against Substitute, which can be problematic against certain variants of Kommo-o and Gyarados. Ditto is also unable to effectively stop bulkier setup sweepers with recovery such as Galarian Slowbro and Reuniclus due to being Choice-locked.
Ditto.comments:
Other Options

Ditto's value is rooted in its revenge killing capabilities, so it should never run anything besides Choice Scarf.

Checks and Counters

Substitute Users: Substitute users like Chandelure and Kommo-o can prevent Ditto from revenge killing them and proceed to wreak havoc.

Choice Scarf Users: Opposing Choice Scarf users will always Speed tie with Ditto and cannot be reliably revenge killed.

Knock Off: Ditto relies on Choice Scarf to outspeed and properly check threats, so it should avoid taking a Knock Off except when it is copying Regenerator or facing a stall team.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description:
Transform is the only move Ditto learns. The provided EVs allow Ditto to do more damage with Future Sight after transforming into a Pokemon like Reuniclus.

Ditto is able to function as a revenge killer on any archetype but is most often found on bulky balance or stall teams that are too passive to efficiently prevent Pokemon from setting up. Chansey is an excellent partner that can get Ditto in safely with Teleport to immediately pressure strong wallbreakers like Salamence and Lycanroc-D. Since Ditto is grounded before transforming, it is vulnerable to all entry hazards besides Sticky Web; entry hazard removal from Salamence and Rotom-H is valuable to keep Ditto healthy. Klefki is able to provide Spikes to wear down the opposing team to better facilitate a countersweep from Ditto. Bulky pivots such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss appreciate Ditto's ability to countersweep, since Pokemon like Salamence often use them as setup fodder. In return, Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into opposing Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude, which Speed tie with Ditto, and sponge Knock Off. Regenerator users such as the aforementioned Reuniclus, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth work well with Ditto, as they can PP stall defensive walls like Chansey together. On stall teams, Pokemon like Haze Quagsire and Spite Pyukumuku can beat bulky Calm Mind users like Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro, which Ditto is unable to revenge kill.

Moltres.overview: Moltres's Fire typing threatens major defensive staples like Amoonguss and Aegislash, and its Flying typing lets it hit common Fire-type answers, such as Keldeo and Kommo-o, super effectively. Defensively, it's a reliable switch-in to Fighting- and Steel-types like Buzzwole and Aegislash, and its immunity to Ground lets it pivot into foes like Mamoswine. It can also punish physical attackers like Krookodile and U-turn users like Jirachi and Zarude due to Flame Body. Its option to run a more defensive Substitute + Toxic set gives it certain versatility too, dealing with conventional checks like Rhyperior, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H way better due to Toxic and PP stalling. However, Moltres's weakness to common offensive typings like Water and Electric hinders it defensively. Its crippling 4x weakness to Rock also leaves it extremely vulnerable to tier staples like Nihilego and Rhyperior, and foes like Krookodile and Zarude can circumvent their vulnerability to Moltres with Rock-type coverage. It also overly relies on its Heavy-Duty Boots and entry hazard removal to not be extremely crippled by Stealth Rock and Knock Off from foes like Mienshao and Krookodile, and its Speed tier, while good, falls short of others like Krookodile and Thundurus-T.
Moltres.comments:
Other Options

An Agility set with Flamethrower, Hurricane, and Roost can act as a late-game cleaner, but finding opportunities to set up Agility can be hard, and Moltres still can't touch Rock-types like Nihilego. Scorching Sands over U-turn or Defog lets offensive Moltres lure in Nihilego and 2HKO it as well as punish switch-ins like Rhyperior with a burn, but it is very niche compared to its alternatives.

Checks and Counters

Knock Off and Stealth Rock: Moltres's 4x weakness to Stealth Rock severely hampers its defensive utility, and losing its Heavy-Duty Boots compromises it for the rest of the game if its teammates can't keep Stealth Rock off of the field.

Rock-types: Nihilego and Rhyperior wall Moltres extremely well, threaten it back with their Rock-type STAB moves, and can punish Defog attempts by putting Stealth Rock back on the field. Nihilego also has the added benefit of walling the Substitute + Toxic set. Lycanroc-D destroys Moltres with its Rock-type STAB attacks but has to be wary of Flame Body if using Accelerock.

Water-types: Primarina and Keldeo can switch into Moltres's Fire-type attacks and threaten it with their Water-type moves, but Keldeo has to be wary of Hurricane, and both hate taking Toxic. RestTalk Primarina, however, has a better matchup against it. Rotom-W doesn't care about any of Moltres's moves other than Toxic and threatens it with Volt Switch and Hydro Pump. It needs to be careful with Hydro Pump's PP if facing the Pressure set, though. Other Water-types like Barraskewda and Starmie are faster than Moltres and can threaten it out of the field, while Milotic and Gastrodon can easily take hits from it, though the former can't switch into Hurricane and the latter two dislike Toxic.

Electric-types: Rotom-H and Rotom-W check the offensive set well, but they can't keep the defensive set at bay for very long, as they are forced to take a Toxic to break the Substitute with Volt Switch. Both Thundurus formes can KO Moltres with Thunderbolt.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower targets Grass- and Steel-types like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, Aegislash, and Celesteela. Fire Blast can be used to hit neutral targets like Hatterene, as well as the aforementioned Grass-types, just as hard as Hurricane but with better accuracy. Hurricane hits Pokemon that resist Fire like Keldeo, Kommo-o, Salamence, and Primarina either super effectively or quite hard neutrally. U-turn lets Moltres keep momentum on Pokemon like Rotom-W and Rhyperior. Defog can be used if Moltres's team can't afford other forms of entry hazard removal. Roost gives Moltres longevity to keep threats like Jirachi and Zarude in check throughout the game, and it keeps Moltres healthy if its Heavy-Duty Boots is removed and Stealth Rock is up. Flame Body is chosen to scare away Pokemon such as Buzzwole, Jirachi, and Mienshao from using contact moves due to a potential burn. 88 HP EVs let Moltres avoid the 2HKO from Zarude's Darkest Lariat.

Bulky offense and balance teams appreciate Moltres pressuring Pokemon like Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Buzzwole. Knock Off absorbers like Buzzwole and Amoonguss make excellent teammates. They're also secondary checks to Mienshao and Zarude so Moltres isn't overwhelmed by them and doesn't have to constantly risk taking the former's Knock Off. Moltres can remove Steel-types such as Aegislash and Cobalion for them in return. Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth check Electric- and Water-types like Thundurus, Rotom-W, and Primarina for Moltres. Jungle Healing Zarude also checks Raikou and Rotom-W, and Choice Scarf variants can revenge kill them and others like Keldeo. Water-types like Keldeo appreciate Moltres dealing with Grass-types like Amoonguss for them, and in return they can pressure Rock-types like Rhyperior for it. Pokemon such as Jirachi and Zarude can form a pivoting core with U-turn Moltres, bringing Moltres in against foes like Tangrowth. If Moltres foregoes Defog, entry hazard removers like Rotom-W and Starmie can help it by keeping Stealth Rock off of the field, and they like Moltres threatening Tangrowth for them. Frail wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Primarina and Thundurus like Moltres's U-turn bringing them in safely against foes like Rhyperior and Salamence.

sets.name: SubToxic
sets.description:
Mystical Fire hits Toxic-immune foes like Amoonguss and Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash, and it weakens special attacks from switch-ins such as Primarina and Nihilego, letting teammates like Tangrowth and Aegislash come into the field more safely. For example, after Stealth Rock, Assault Vest Tangrowth is no longer 2HKOed by Choice Specs Primarina's Moonblast at -1. Toxic is Moltres's main way of harming foes like Rotom-W, Salamence, and Kommo-o. Substitute gives Moltres a decoy against moves like Rotom-W's Hydro Pump and Rhyperior's Stone Edge and lets it PP stall them. It also eases prediction when foes switch out and blocks status from Pokemon like Amoonguss and Aegislash. Pressure lets Moltres stall moves with low PP like Primarina's Hydro Pump and Buzzwole's Stone Edge. The given EV spread minimizes the chance of the Rotom formes breaking Moltres's Substitute with Volt Switch after using Roost while still avoiding the 2HKO from Zarude's Darkest Lariat. 224 Speed EVs let Moltres outspeed the Rotom formes and Buzzwole.

This set fits on balance and stall teams, where Moltres can slowly wear down checks like Rotom-H and Rhyperior with Toxic and PP stall others like Rotom-W and Buzzwole. Zarude and Amoonguss can pressure RestTalk Primarina, which limits Moltres from making progress throughout the game. Moltres in return deals with Grass-types that bother Zarude, like Amoonguss. Jirachi, Aegislash, and Choice Scarf Krookodile check Nihilego, a major roadblock to this set, and deal with Lycanroc-D. The former can also bring Moltres safely against Steel-types like Aegislash. Entry hazard removers like Salamence and Starmie make for great partners. The former likes Moltres crippling Primarina and Rhyperior, while the latter appreciates Moltres threatening Tangrowth and crippling Milotic and Quagsire. Chansey takes care of the special attackers Moltres can't handle, like Nihilego and Thundurus-T. On stall teams, Umbreon provides cleric support with Heal Bell and Wish, and it also deals with Gyarados. Quagsire walls Electric- and Rock-types like Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D, and Amoonguss acts as a Knock Off absorber and secondary check to Keldeo and Primarina. They appreciate Moltres spreading Toxic and threatening Buzzwole and other physical attackers with Flame Body.

Moltres-Galar.overview: Galarian Moltres is both an offensive and defensive threat in UU. Its fantastic bulk and defensive typing allow Galarian Moltres to fill a defensive role by using a RestTalk set that is one of the few Pokemon capable of defeating all variations of Aegislash. Such sets can almost singlehandedly defeat stall teams and perform as a great status absorber to the omnipresent Amoonguss and Chansey. Galarian Moltres can also run a more offensive set on hyper offense with Nasty Plot and Agility. Coupled with STAB attacks that provide near-perfect coverage, Galarian Moltres can be remarkably hard to stop after it sets up. However, having only base 100 Special Attack can prevent Galarian Moltres from breaking through specially bulky Pokemon such as Rhyperior and Nihilego, even when boosted. Galarian Moltres also requires two turns to set up if a Weakness Policy is not used or activated, which leaves it vulnerable to Taunt and status afflictions. Using RestTalk can make Galarian Moltres too passive when first entering a battle, so the set can be challenging to fit onto teams due to how often it invites wallbreakers such as Azumarill and Kommo-o to come in. Lastly, despite an overall good defensive typing, Galarian Moltres is weak to common priority moves such as Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Mamoswine's Ice Shard.
Moltres-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Taunt is a passable option on either set, but it has a huge opportunity cost over any of the listed moves. Forgoing a STAB or boosting move for Substitute is an option on the Double Dance set to give Galarian Moltres a better matchup against offensive teams, and it can even function decently alongside Salac Berry or Petaya Berry depending on which boosting move is being used, but overall is less reliable. A pivot set with Heavy-Duty Boots and U-turn can check many Pokemon as well as grab momentum for your team, but it leaves a lot to be desired when it comes to power.

Checks and Counters

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Lycanroc-D and Rhyperior pose a huge threat to Galarian Moltres; Lycanroc-D can halt a sweep with priority Accelerock, and Rhyperior can tank a hit and wear Moltres down with Rock Blast or Toxic. Nihilego and Diancie also serve as great checks, as the former can take any boosted attack and retaliate with a Rock-type STAB attack, while the latter flat out counters Moltres.

Fairy-types: Azumarill and Primarina are capable of OHKOing either Galarian Moltres set. Bulkier variants of Primarina can take boosted Hurricane to boot. Diancie can hit Moltres hard with Diamond Storm and shrug off any attack Galarian Moltres tries to hit it with.

Taunt: If Galarian Moltres has Taunt used on it, it will be unable to set up with its offensive set or recover and attack with Sleep Talk on its bulky set. Krookodile is a common Taunt user that can outspeed Galarian Moltres and prevent it from using setup or recovery moves. Most Taunt users can usually only proactively halt Galarian Moltres from making progress, however, as either set can do a lot of damage to them when boosted.

Electric-types: Electric-types such as Raikou, Thundurus-T, and Thundurus OHKO or heavily dent Galarian Moltres.

Priority: Powerful priority moves, with the exception of Sucker Punch, are some of the quickest ways to halt a Galarian Moltres's sweep. Most notably, Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Mamoswine's Ice Shard.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
RestTalk Galarian Moltres can provide a lot of utility to a team by checking and breaking through foes like Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro. Fiery Wrath is the main attack on this set, as it has acceptable coverage and is reliable. Hurricane is preferable on Galarian Moltres, as it prevents it giving free switches to a range of potent offensive threats such as Keldeo, Primarina, and Kommo-o. Nasty Plot is an option over Hurricane, as it provides the necessary power to overwhelm Pokemon like Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro. Rest and Sleep Talk allow Galarian Moltres to effectively check foes like Aegislash, absorb status, and lets it accumulate Berserk boosts. The Speed EVs let Galarian Moltres outspeed Aegislash, while the rest of the EVs with a Calm nature go towards special bulk to help Galarian Moltres against special attackers such as Aegislash and special Salamence. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Galarian Moltres from taking Stealth Rock damage, easing the need for it to use Rest often.

This set can be challenging to fit onto teams because it has a very unique role and is vulnerable to powerful wallbreakers such as Primarina and Azumarill. It fares best on bulky offense and balance builds, however. Azumarill is a helpful partner to this set, as it is able to break through just about any special wall that can threaten Galarian Moltres, particularly Rhyperior and the rare Diancie. Galarian Moltres can help Azumarill by providing an ideal matchup against Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Assault Vest Tangrowth can help check Electric-types like Thundurus-T and Thundurus that can take advantage of Galarian Moltres, especially after using Rest. Buzzwole is a great partner that can help check foes like Lycanroc-D, Cobalion, and Obstagoon, as well as act as a better Knock Off absorber against the likes of Krookodile. In return, Galarian Moltres can check Pokemon like Amoonguss and Aegislash that limit Buzzwole from spamming its STAB moves. Diancie can provide Heal Bell support to wake Galarian Moltres up after it has used Rest. Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash are extremely important partners, checking one of Moltres-Galar's biggest checks in Nihilego. Jirachi can also provide Wish support so that Galarian Moltres doesn't have to use Rest as often.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description:
After using both Nasty Plot and Agility, Galarian Moltres can OHKO most the metagame and outspeeds the entirety of it, with the exception of weather abusers like Barraskewda. The only attacks needed here are STAB attacks Fiery Wrath and Hurricane, as the only UU-relevant Pokemon they miss out on are the rare Klefki and Diancie. Fiery Wrath's flinch chance also can give Galarian Moltres chances to break through bulkier Pokemon that can tank its attacks such as Chansey. Air Slash is an option over Hurricane if accuracy concerns arise. Weakness Policy is the optimal item for this set, as the most effective way to take down Galarian Moltres is a super effective attack, meaning it activates a decent amount of the time and gives Galarian Moltres exceptional power when coupled with Nasty Plot. Using Weakness Policy can also create opportunities for Galarian Moltres to set up in one turn by using Agility as a super effective attack hits it. Heavy-Duty Boots is also a viable item choice, as preventing Stealth Rock damage can make it much more challenging for an opponent to take down Galarian Moltres.

Double Dance Galarian Moltres fits almost exclusively on hyper offense teams. Stealth Rock setters rack up chip damage on Pokemon that check Galarian Moltres such as Diancie. Krookodile is the most notable one, as it provides Stealth Rock, an Electric-type immunity, Intimidate, and a good enough Speed tier to shut down most opposing entry hazard setters with Taunt. Physical sweepers that fit well on hyper offense teams and can break through or soften up specially bulky Pokemon able to halt a Galarian Moltres sweep—such as Chansey and Nihilego—are appreciated as partners. Belly Drum Azumarill can fill this role; in return, Galarian Moltres has a great matchup against Grass-types that trouble Azumarill. Gyarados and Swords Dance Aegislash are also decent picks on hyper offense teams that can break through special tanks. Alolan Ninetales can provide Aurora Veil support to give Galarian Moltres an easier time setting up as it becomes exceptionally difficult to take down behind screens.

Azumarill.overview: Azumarill is an offensive powerhouse and effective wallbreaker when equipped with a Choice Band due to Huge Power. It can also utilize a Belly Drum set to be a scary late-game cleaner. Water / Fairy is a great offensive typing, allowing Azumarill to beat key threats like Krookodile and Keldeo. Access to great coverage moves such as Knock Off and Ice Punch lets Azumarill break past Pokemon like Volcanion and Tangrowth that would otherwise check it by resisting its STAB combination, while access to Aqua Jet allows it to also be a great revenge killer, especially against top threats like Lycanroc-D and Thundurus that have taken chip damage. Azumarill also has decent natural bulk and a great defensive typing, which allows it to blanket check some of the more dangerous threats in the metagame such as Kommo-o and Salamence. Unfortunately, Azumarill is quite slow, so it is easily forced out by faster Pokemon such as Raikou and Thundurus when it is not boosted with Belly Drum. Additionally, Rotom-W and faster Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Zarude can revenge kill Azumarill, as they can stomach a +6 Aqua Jet. Belly Drum Azumarill is restricted to only getting one setup opportunity, which usually forces it to be preserved until late-game.
Azumarill.comments:
Other Options

An Assault Vest set can help Azumarill more comfortably switch into Keldeo, Salamence, and Galarian Moltres and KO them back and also come in and pressure neutral special attackers like Primarina. It is typically not advisable, though, as Azumarill loses out on a lot of wallbreaking power and most special attackers have the means to overwhelm it regardless. Azumarill can run a trapping set with Sap Sipper and Whirlpool, Perish Song, and Protect. This can trap passive foes like Celesteela as well as Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but the effectiveness of this set is purely restricted to punishing walls and is deadweight against a majority of the offensive threats in UU.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Faster Grass-types like Zarude and Venusaur are the biggest threats to Azumarill because even a Belly Drum Azumarill cannot OHKO them with Aqua Jet and they OHKO back. Defensive Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth can usually switch into Choice Band Azumarill and threaten it with their own STAB moves as well as scout and switch out with Regenerator.

Faster Water-resistant Pokemon: Anything faster that resists Aqua Jet is bound to pressure Azumarill. These Pokemon include Gyarados, Tentacruel, and Rotom-W. Salamence can also pressure Azumarill, but it is also pressured by Azumarill with Play Rough, so Azumarill would have to be significantly chipped for Salamence to KO it. Volcanion is immune to Aqua Jet and can threaten Azumarill with Sludge Wave.

Electric-types: An unboosted Azumarill is easy prey for Raikou and Thundurus. Without being at +6, Azumarill cannot come close to KOing them with Aqua Jet, and both will in turn OHKO Azumarill. Rotom-W resists Aqua Jet and can also outspeed and cripple Azumarill with Will-O-Wisp or pressure it with an Electric-type attack.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Play Rough is Azumarill's main attack to remove foes like Zarude, Kommo-o, and Tangrowth. Aqua Jet becomes a very powerful STAB priority move when bolstered by Huge Power and a Choice Band, allowing it to OHKO Nihilego and revenge kill Thundurus and Rotom-H after they have taken sufficient chip damage. Ice Punch allows Azumarill to break through Amoonguss by hitting it hard enough to 2HKO on the switch. Knock Off can be used to burden anything that switches in, such as Tangrowth and Tentacruel, by removing their item. A Choice Band allows Azumarill to maximize the wallbreaking potential its STAB attacks have to offer. Adamant is the preferred nature to make it as strong as possible.

Choice Band Azumarill fits best on bulky offense teams. It wants to be brought in as often as possible early-game to wallbreak, so having good pivots such as Thundurus and Jirachi is extremely useful. Azumarill wants to fire off its STAB moves frequently, but it struggles to do so against bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Nidoking, Moltres, and Salamence can remove these Pokemon and make Azumarill's job easier. Kommo-o can offensively pressure Grass-types with its mixed set and can also check Volcanion. Keeping entry hazards up is important to ease Azumarill's ability to break through Tangrowth, so partners such as Krookodile and Nihilego are essential. Tapu Bulu and Zarude threaten to revenge kill Azumarill, as they are faster and resist Aqua Jet, so partners like Salamence and Amoonguss that can comfortably switch into them are ideal. Having a good Electric-immune teammate, such as Krookodile, Seismitoad, or Nidoking, helps to deal with Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus, which are all faster than Azumarill and threaten to OHKO or significantly damage it.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
A +6 Aqua Jet will KO almost anything that doesn't resist it, so it is very hard for anything to revenge kill Azumarill. Play Rough is used to pressure slower threats after a boost, as it can OHKO anything that does not resist it, including a fully defensive Tangrowth. A boosted Knock Off will OHKO Amoonguss and defensive Celesteela. Sitrus Berry allows Azumarill to set up more reliably and puts it at a comfortable amount of HP after a Belly Drum. Adamant is the preferred nature to guarantee an OHKO on Amoonguss with Knock Off.

Belly Drum Azumarill fits best on hyper offense teams due to its nature as a late-game cleaner and need for dedicated support. Boosted Aqua Jet can still KO Water-resistant foes like Tentacruel after substantial chip damage, so a hazard setter can help chip these Pokemon to allow Azumarill to KO them later on. Krookodile and Kommo-o are good options for this, and the former also provides an Electric immunity. A teammate that can pivot, such as Cobalion or Thundurus, can help Azumarill come in safely to set up a Belly Drum and also chip foes while doing so. Once Azumarill is boosted with Belly Drum, it typically will not get another chance to do so. As such, before it can come in and sweep, it needs teammates to help eliminate its main threats, which are mostly Pokemon that resist Water, are faster, and can KO it. Good offensive teammates include Salamence and Aegislash to help take out foes like Zarude and Keldeo. Thundurus-T can also hit most of Azumarill's checks with its coverage options, and it also provides a valuable Electric immunity.

Quagsire.overview: Quagsire possesses a unique niche in the UU metagame with its ability in Unaware, which lets it stop setup sweepers such as Scizor and Dragon Dance Salamence in their tracks. A Water / Ground typing allows Quagsire to act as a Volt Switch absorber while also checking Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D. As such, these attributes make Quagsire a staple on stall teams. However, Quagsire's 4x weakness to Grass makes it unable to check Pokemon such as Nihilego and Gyarados, as they commonly carry Grass-type coverage. Quagsire's bulk only goes so far, as very strong wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Azumarill can break through it with minimal effort. Finally, Quagsire's poor special bulk leaves it unable to take on special attackers well, leaving it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Thundurus-T and Keldeo.
Quagsire.comments:
Other Options

A Curse set turns Quagsire into a bulky sweeper, but it will need many boosts before it can cause serious damage and is even more vulnerable to Grass-types. Additionally, it must drop Scald from its moveset, making Quagsire much more passive.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Moves: Grass-types resist any attack Quagsire throws at them and proceed to force it out. Amoonguss deserves a special mention, as it is immune to Toxic and can recover any lost health with Regenerator. Pokemon that can lure in Quagsire and KO it with a coverage move, such as Gyarados and Nihilego, are also threats to Quagsire.

Strong Physical Attackers: Quagsire's bulk is only decent; extremely strong attacks coming from the likes of Buzzwole and Diggersby will easily overwhelm it. Haxorus can also easily overpower Quagsire with Mold Breaker ignoring Unaware.

Special Attackers: Quagsire's mediocre special bulk makes it unable to stomach many special attacks, and as such, strong special attackers like Primarina and Azelf can easily break through it.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Scald has a good chance to burn threats such as Scizor and Tapu Bulu. Earthquake hits Pokemon such as Raikou, Jirachi, and Nihilego. Haze stops setup sweepers such as Galarian Slowbro and Reuniclus in their tracks. Toxic is an option that cripples switch-ins such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o, but it has to give up Scald or the utility of Haze to do so. Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to avoid damage from Spikes and Toxic Spikes; however, Quagsire is already resistant to Stealth Rock, and the passive recovery brought by Leftovers is generally much more appreciated. The given EV spread allows Quagsire to take on special attackers such as Rotom-W more comfortably while maximizing its physical bulk.

Quagsire fits best on stall teams, stopping setup sweepers with Unaware. Amoonguss and Tangrowth are excellent partners for Quagsire, as they check Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude. Additionally, these Pokemon are able to check wallbreakers that Quagsire struggles with, such as Conkeldurr. Chansey forms a solid defensive core with Quagsire, being able to check special attackers such as Nihilego and Thundurus-T, while Quagsire checks physical threats for it in return. Chansey's Heal Bell also allows it to cure status that easily wear down Quagsire. Other clerics such as Umbreon and Mew are also good options to pair with Quagsire. As Quagsire can be overwhelmed by strong physical wallbreakers while Spikes are in play, Pokemon that provide Defog support such as Mew and Salamence are highly recommend. Ditto can provide offensive support and deter setup sweepers like Haxorus and Crawdaunt that Quagsire can't deal with properly.

Shuckle.overview: Shuckle stands out as a Sticky Web user with its ability to set Stealth Rock and natural bulk. Sturdy alongside Shuckle's natural bulk allows it to get both entry hazards with Custap Berry. Shuckle also has options such as Final Gambit and Toxic to run in its other two moveslots to avoid being too passive. However, Shuckle is unable to contribute much outside of getting up entry hazards, unlike Ribombee and Araquanid, which have actual offensive presence. Shuckle also competes with Slurpuff, which can wear down Aegislash with Flamethrower and run Endeavor. While Shuckle can annoy Pokemon with Encore, it cannot prevent Defog from Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Salamence due to its passive nature with the exception of Custap Berry + Final Gambit. Not running Mental Herb also leaves Shuckle vulnerable to Taunt.
Shuckle.comments:
Other Options

Infestation lets Shuckle trap other passive Pokemon like Amoonguss and get up both entry hazards before switching into a setup sweeper. Infestation generally works best with Encore, as this combination allows for easier setup.

Checks and Counters

Taunt and Encore Users: Krookodile and Mew can use Taunt to prevent Shuckle from getting up entry hazards if it is not running Mental Herb. Alolan Ninetales can stop Shuckle from setting up both Stealth Rock and Sticky Web with Encore.

Hatterene: Magic Bounce prevents Shuckle from getting up entry hazards. Hatterene is also not bothered much by Knock Offand is free to set up with Calm Mind on Shuckle.

Entry Hazard Removers: Pokemon like Volcanion, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel can easily switch into Shuckle and remove its entry hazards with Defog or Rapid Spin. Tentacruel is also immune to Toxic,(AC) and Rotom-W can use Volt Switch to gain momentum.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Custap Berry in combination with Sturdy grants Shuckle a turn to get a second entry hazard up, gain momentum with Final Gambit and prevent Defog, or cripple the foe with Encore, Knock Off, or Toxic. Encore prevents Pokemon like Gyarados and Kommo-o from immediately setting up on Shuckle. Knock Off gives Shuckle some utility and removes Heavy-Duty Boots or Choice Scarf from Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Zarude. Toxic cripples Pokemon like Keldeo and Rotom-H. Although, if Shuckle doesn't take enough damage for Custap Berry to activate, then it can be 2HKOed with only one entry hazard up. Mental Herb prevents Shuckle from being affected by Taunt. Red Card is an alternative option to prevent foes from setting up on Shuckle, but this can backfire by drawing a Defogger in. Physical bulk investment gives Shuckle more staying power against Pokemon like Krookodile.

Shuckle should only be used on hyper offense teams in order to make the most of its ability to set both Sticky Web and Stealth Rock and be played aggressively to avoid entry hazard removal. Some strong wallbreakers that can take advantage of Sticky Web are Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Kommo-o. Mamoswine is able to check opposing Kommo-o, Diggersby beats Jirachi, and Kommo-o can finish Lycanroc-D without a Speed boost. They can also pressure entry hazard removers such as Rotom-H, defensive Salamence, and Tentacruel. Thundurus-T is able to patch up its lackluster Speed tier and wallbreak easier under Sticky Web, outpacing Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, while also serving as an Electric-type immunity. Aegislash is another strong wallbreaker that's able to capitalize on Sticky Web and check Mamoswine and Lycanroc-D. Aegislash and Azumarill are great setup sweepers on Sticky Web teams, as they have priority to clean with should Sticky Web be removed. Under Sticky Web, they are able to deal with Jirachi and offensive Buzzwole, respectively.

Raikou.overview: With its solid Special Attack, a Speed stat that outpaces nearly the entire metagame, and good special bulk, Raikou is able to make a name for itself as a solid offensive pivot that can check tier staples like Lycanroc-D, Thundurus, and Keldeo. Access to Aura Sphere and Scald along with its STAB Thunderbolt gives Raikou near-perfect coverage against the entire metagame. This coverage, along with its stats and access to Volt Switch, makes Raikou a solid choice for an offensive pivot. Raikou struggles to deal with defensive staples, however, notably Amoonguss and Chansey. It also lacks a form of reliable recovery, which forces it to function mainly as a revenge killer and makes it overly reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots. Raikou also faces strong competition as a fast Electric-type by Thundurus, which has stronger coverage moves, can use U-turn as a pivoting move to prevent being blocked by Ground-types, and can use Knock Off to cripple Pokemon like Assault Vest Tangrowth that Raikou greatly struggles with, though it does have worse special bulk and a worse Speed tier than Raikou. Raikou's subpar physical bulk means that it is easily threatened by several physical attackers it cannot OHKO, like Krookodile and Mamoswine.
Raikou.comments:
Other Options

Substitute and Calm Mind can be used to give Raikou some extra breaking power with either Aura Sphere or Scald, preferably the latter to hit Zarude while still being to hit Rhyperior, as the coverage move, but in a metagame infested with Assault Vest Tangrowth, it is very hard to make this set work.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Tangrowth only takes neutral damage from Aura Sphere, and can take those well due to commonly running Assault Vest. Amoonguss resists all of Raikou's coverage moves, walling it with ease. Zarude can easily wall most of Raikou's attacks and, if holding a Choice Scarf, easily pivot out on it with U-Turn, though it does have to watch out for Aura Sphere. The former two Pokemon also have Regenerator, which means that they are not punished as hard by Raikou's Volt Switch.

Ground-types: Choice Scarf Krookodile, Choice Scarf Diggersby, and Zygarde-10% can all outspeed or Speed tie Raikou and use their super effective moves to OHKO it. Rhyperior can also serve as a major threat and can scare Raikou out if its HP is high enough; however, it does have to be extremely wary of Scald. Gastrodon and Seismitoad are able to completely wall Raikou with ease, though they do fear Toxic.

Kommo-o: Kommo-o either resists or is immune to all of Raikou's attacking moves and can easily turn it into setup fodder if it is running a Clangorous Soul set, although physical and mixed sets do have to worry about being burned by Scald. It also has no reliable recovery, and thus gets worn down easily by multiple Volt Switches as well as Toxic.

Specially Defensive Walls: Chansey's enormous special bulk allows it to wall Raikou, even if it has Aura Sphere. However, Chansey does not like switching into Volt Switch, especially when hazards are up. Assault Vest Reuniclus and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can also sponge Raikou's attacks easily, though the former does have to watch out for Toxic.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Thunderbolt is Raikou's main method of pressuring Pokemon like Thundurus and Aegislash. Volt Switch turns Raikou into a fast offensive pivot, allowing it to make progress and bring its teammates onto the field. Aura Sphere is especially useful, as it allows Raikou to hit Zarude, which completely walls it otherwise. Scald allows Raikou to hit Nidoking, another Pokemon that completely walls it otherwise. It can also be used to hit Rhyperior for more damage and spread status to checks like Tangrowth, and it is Raikou's best move against Thundurus-T. Toxic allows Raikou to cripple switch-ins like Tangrowth and Kommo-o that resist both Thunderbolt and Scald, as well as crippling Rhyperior in the absence of Scald. Heavy-Duty Boots prevent Raikou from taking entry hazard damage, increasing its pivoting capabilities.

This Raikou set works best on VoltTurn and bulky offense teams that appreciate Raikou's high Speed tier and its ability to check Thundurus and Lycanroc-D. Flying-types like Salamence, Noivern, and Moltres are excellent partners for this set. Powerful wallbreakers, like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Mamoswine, appreciate Raikou bringing them in safely against its checks, such as Chansey and Amoonguss, which they can then pressure. Keldeo is an especially good partner for Raikou, as together they can overwhelm their shared checks, such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Pokemon that can pivot into Ground-types, particularly Rhyperior, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon, are greatly appreciated, especially if Raikou is not running Scald. Grass-types, such as Zarude and Tangrowth, are especially good at dealing with these Pokemon. Raikou greatly appreciates entry hazard support from Pokemon like Kommo-o, which allows it to wear down its checks like Tangrowth in combination with Volt Switch.

Suicune.overview: Despite its average movepool, Suicune is a decent setup sweeper due to its astounding bulk and valuable defensive typing that allow it to check distinguished threats such as Rhyperior. With Pressure, Calm Mind, and its superb bulk, Suicune is able to stall out threatening walls such as Aegislash and Chansey.
